title: Project

title: Project
text: simulation mimics experiment participants presented series quantitative stimuli provide response . analyses, quantitative stimuli serve independent variable(s) participants’ responses serve dependent variable. Importantly, string stimuli repeated multiple times throughout study, allowing us compute test-retest reliablity (see Vanhasbroeck et al., 2024). step simulation, generate data given set participants generative model estimate parameters another estimation model. parameter sets subjected analysis, computing several statistics targeting compensatory mechanisms (e.g., bias standard errors) parameter reliability (e.g., intra-class correlation coefficient). Importantly, parameters estimated individual-specific level. Throughout simulation, vary number participants (25, 100, 500), number repetitions stimuli (2, 3, 4, 5), number stimuli per repetition (15, 25, 50, 100). simulation condition repeated 1000 times, allowing us fine-grained look relevant statistics. Parameters models drawn uniform distributions bounds [−10,10][-10, 10] intercepts [−5,5][-5, 5] slopes.

title: Project
text: step simulation, compare parametric performance one model (estimation model) fit data generated another model (generative model). estimation model generative model different, speak misspecification, primary interest study. models use study following: Linear:yt=β0+β1xtQuadratic:yt=β0+β1xt+β2xt2Cubic:yt=β0+β1xt+β2xt2+β3x3Main effects:yt=β0+β1xt+β2ztInteraction effects:yt=β0+β1xt+β2zt+β3xtzt\begin{equation} \begin{array}{ll}     \text{Linear:} & y_t = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x_t \\     \text{Quadratic:} & y_t = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x_t + \beta_2 x_t^2 \\     \text{Cubic:} & y_t = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x_t + \beta_2 x_t^2 + \beta_3 x^3 \\     \text{Main effects:} & y_t = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x_t + \beta_2 z_t \\     \text{Interaction effects:} & y_t = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x_t + \beta_2 z_t + \beta_3 x_t z_t \\ \end{array} \end{equation} models selected based use literature, linear, quadratic, cubic model often used investigate shape relation dependent independent variable, main interaction effect models often used statistical analyses. Comparisons models done theoretically interesting ways. Specifically, compare nested nonnested models, allowing us nontrivial look compensatory mechanisms. following nested models compared : Linear - Quadratic Quadratic - Cubic Main effects - Interaction effects Additionally, compared following nonnested models : : CHOOSE MODELS + CHOOSE COMPUTE SNR ETC. Note models can serve generative model estimation model, allowing us look effect - -parametrization.

title: Project
text: First, compute directed undirected bias, compute : Bdirected=1n∑=1n(θestimated−θgenerative)Bundirected=1n∑=1n|θestimated−θgenerative|\begin{equation} \begin{array}{l}     \text{B}_\text{directed} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{= 1}^n (\theta_\text{estimated} - \theta_\text{generative}) \\     \text{B}_\text{undirected} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{= 1}^n |\theta_\text{estimated} - \theta_\text{generative}| \end{array} \end{equation} θ\theta represents parameter generative estimation models. Second, compute relative bias, examines size bias relative total variation. study, computed : RB=∑=1n(θestimated−θgenerative)θgenerative\begin{equation}     \text{RB} = \frac{\sum_{= 1}^n (\theta_\text{estimated} - \theta_\text{generative})}{\theta_\text{generative}} \end{equation} Third, compute mean squared error measure accuracy estimates, defining : MSE=1n∑=1n(θestimated−θgenerative)2\begin{equation}     \text{MSE} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{= 1}^n (\theta_\text{estimated} - \theta_\text{generative})^2 \end{equation} Finally, compute coverage rate parameter. , make use estimated value standard error parameter construct 95%CI around estimated value parameter assumption normality, specifically (NOTE: HIGHER SE, LIKELY COVER. MAYBE NEED LOOK SE WELL?): 95%CI=[θestimated−1.96×SE,θestimated+1.96×SE]\begin{equation}     95\%CI = [\theta_\text{estimated} - 1.96 \times \text{SE}, \theta_\text{estimated} + 1.96 \times \text{SE}] \end{equation} SE denotes standard error 1.96 represents critical values normal distribution. Coverage indicated checking whether θgenerative\theta_\text{generative} lies inside CI . Aggregating across different parameter sets, get coverage percentage, interest .

title: Project
text: First, compute intra-class correlation coefficient ICC(, 1), checking well values parameters match across different repetitions strings. serves measure test-retest reliability. study, defined : ICC(, 1)=σparticipant2σtotal2\begin{equation}     \text{ICC(, 1)} = \frac{\sigma_\text{participant}^2}{\sigma_\text{total}^2} \end{equation} σparticipant2\sigma_\text{participant}^2 variance parameter can attributed participants (.e., individual differences) σtotal2\sigma_\text{total}^2 total observed variance parameter. Second, compute coefficient variation, relates observed variation parameter’s value value parameter. symbols: CV=σ|μ|\begin{equation}     \text{CV} = \frac{\sigma}{| \mu |} \end{equation} σ\sigma μ\mu standard deviation mean estimated parameter respectively. Finally, compute signal--noise ratio, defined : SNR=E[S2]E[N2]\begin{equation}     \text{SNR} = \frac{E[S^2]}{E[N^2]} \end{equation} SS NN represent signal noise respectively. case, two components can computed : E[S2]=1n∑=1nθgenerative2E[N2]=1n∑=1n(θgenerative−θestimated)2\begin{equation} \begin{array}{l}     E[S^2] = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{= 1}^n \theta_\text{generative}^2 \\     E[N^2] = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{= 1}^n (\theta_\text{generative} - \theta_\text{estimated})^2 \end{array} \end{equation} θ\theta represents parameter models.

title: Project
text: Vanhasbroeck, N., Vanbelle, S., Moors, ., Vanpaemel, W., & Tuerlinckx, F. (2024). Chasing consistency: measurement error self-reported affect experiments. Behavior Research Methods, 56(4), 3009-3022. doi: 10.3758/s13428-023-02290-3 Yu, K., Lin, T.-Y., Zaman, J., Tuerlinckx, F., & Vanhasbroeck, N. (2025). Consistency perceptual response variability size estimation reproduction tasks. Behavior Research Methods, 57, Article 127. doi: 10.3758/s13428-025-02650-1

title: Simulation
text: first thing understand models, defined model.R. S4 classes define models use simulation study. model consists set parameters within-person standard deviation, can provided values attributes parameters sd. example, creating linear model calling my_model, get: piece code, intercept given value 10 slope x given value 5. can retrieve parameters calling attributes: can also change values parameters attributes: Note initialize model, necessarily specify arguments: Instead, default parameter settings used.
code: my_model <- linear(     parameters = c(10, 5),     sd = 2 ) my_model ## An object of class "linear" ## Slot "parameters": ## [1] 10  5 ##  ## Slot "sd": ## [1] 2 my_model@parameters ## [1] 10  5 my_model@sd ## [1] 2 my_model@parameters <- c(-10, -5) my_model@sd <- 0.5  my_model@parameters ## [1] -10  -5 my_model@sd ## [1] 0.5 my_model <- linear()  my_model@parameters ## [1] 0 0 my_model@sd ## [1] 1

title: Simulation
text: primary function use generating parameters parameter_grid, create given number parameter sets particular model. Using function requires passing model interested . example, linear model, can : output function matrix size n×kn \times k, nn number parameter sets generated kk represents number parameters model. case, get 25×225 \times 2 matrix. additional arguments, can control parameter generation process. Specifically, one can change number parameter sets generated, process used generation parameters, bounds parameters. Focusing first number parameters generated, one can change values n_int n_slope, respectively denoting number different intercepts slopes one wants generate. example: first piece code results 100×2100 \times 2 matrix second piece code results 400×2400 \times 2 matrix. get values? default, function parameter_grid sample parameter values ordered manner within specified bounds parameters. argument n_int n_slope define number unique, equally spaced values wish sample within interval, n_int controls number intercept parameters n_slope slope parameters. type simulation allows well-controlled simulation study, may lack generalizability across different simulation studies number unique parameters differs greatly. therefore allow another type parameter generation process specifying argument n, example: output 100×k100 \times k parameter matrix, matter model provide function. words, always end 100 unique parameter sets. way achieve uniform sampling across bounds parameters. guarantee parameters cover entire possible range, gains generalizability across different models simulation. Finally, can change bounds intercepts slopes intercept slope parameters, provide minimum maximum value parameter. example:

title: Simulation
text: heavy lifting running simulation done execute_study function. minimum, function requires generative estimation model defined, can call: important arguments can change function following: n_participants, n_outcomes, n_bins: Integers denoting number participants study number bins outcomes per bin include experiment. parameter_sd: Numeric denoting standard deviation parameters across participants (.e., individual differences). ICC: Numeric 0 1 denoting ICC wish simulate, pitting -subject differences within-person differences. statistics: Named list containing functions compute statistics interest (see statistics.R details). changing values arguments, can run small simulation study : output function named list containing output functions provided statistics. serve primary unit analysis.
code: sim_model <- linear() est_model <- quadratic()  execute_study(     sim_model,      est_model ) sim_model <- linear() est_model <- quadratic()  execute_study(     sim_model,      est_model,     n_participants = 10,      n_outcomes = 15,      n_bins = 5,      ICC = 0.8,     statistics = list(         "icc" = icc,          "signal" = signal     ) ) ## $icc ##   parameter        icc systematic   residual ## 1 intercept 0.59547450  0.6547292 0.44477914 ## 2   slope_1 0.57431435  0.5830172 0.43213625 ## 3   slope_2 0.06873378  0.0035012 0.04743736 ##  ## $signal ##   parameter coefficient_variation signal_to_noise ## 1 intercept              1.796748        6.651522 ## 2   slope_1              3.760290        7.209125 ## 3   slope_2             16.963877        0.000000

title: An S4 Class to Represent the ar1 Model. — ar1-class
text: Defines ar1 class, states given dependent variable \(y\), previous values variable part determine current values variable: $$y_{t} = + by_{t - 1}$$ class solely defined parameters \(\) \(b\), provided construction class.

title: An S4 Class to Represent the ar1 Model. — ar1-class
text: parameters Numeric vector containing values parameters model, namely \(\) \(b\) order. left unspecified, model default c(0, 0). sd Numeric defining error around deterministic part defined slot parameters. left unspecified, default 1

what: Get the Bounds of the Model — bounds
title: Get the Bounds of the Model — bounds
text: Get Bounds Model

title: Get the Bounds of the Model — bounds
code: bounds(model, ...)  # S4 method for class 'linear' bounds(model, intercept = c(-10, 10), slope = c(-5, 5))  # S4 method for class 'quadratic' bounds(model, intercept = c(-10, 10), slope = c(-5, 5))  # S4 method for class 'cubic' bounds(model, intercept = c(-10, 10), slope = c(-5, 5))  # S4 method for class 'main_effect' bounds(model, intercept = c(-10, 10), slope = c(-5, 5))  # S4 method for class 'interaction' bounds(model, intercept = c(-10, 10), slope = c(-5, 5))  # S4 method for class 'ar1' bounds(model, intercept = c(-10, 10), slope = c(-5, 5))  # S4 method for class 'arx' bounds(model, intercept = c(-10, 10), slope = c(-5, 5))

title: Get the Bounds of the Model — bounds
text: model Object one different model classes (e.g., linear, quadratic,...) ... Additional arguments provided model choice. intercept Numeric vector two values denoting lower upper bound intercept parameter. Defaults c(-10, 10). slope Numeric vector two values denoting lower upper bound slope parameters covariates. Defaults c(-5, 5).

title: Get the Bounds of the Model — bounds
text: Matrix left/right column specifies lower/upper bounds parameters order specified description models

title: Get the Bounds of the Model — bounds
code: # Example given for the linear model, but also possible for the other models bounds(linear()) #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]  -10   10 #> [2,]   -5    5  bounds(   linear(),   intercept = c(-10, 10),   slope = c(0, 10) ) #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]  -10   10 #> [2,]    0   10

title: An S4 Class to Represent the Cubic Model. — cubic-class
text: S4 Class Represent Cubic Model.

title: An S4 Class to Represent the Cubic Model. — cubic-class
text: Defines cubic class, states given input \(x\), relationship \(x\) dependent variable \(y\) quadratic: $$y = + bx + cx^2 + dx^3$$ class solely defined parameters \(\), \(b\), \(c\), \(d\), provided construction class.

title: An S4 Class to Represent the Cubic Model. — cubic-class
text: parameters Numeric vector containing values parameters model, namely \(\), \(b\), \(c\) order. left unspecified, model default c(0, 0, 0, 0). sd Numeric defining error around deterministic part defined slot parameters. left unspecified, default 1

what: Compute the Descriptive Statistics for the Parameters — descriptives
title: Compute the Descriptive Statistics for the Parameters — descriptives
text: Descriptive statistics include mean, standard deviation, median, 95 confidence interval across participants. Statistics computed per bin-type.

title: Compute the Descriptive Statistics for the Parameters — descriptives
code: descriptives(data)

title: Compute the Descriptive Statistics for the Parameters — descriptives
text: data Named list containing parameter names "parameters", true parameter values "simulated", estimated parameter values "estimated". Typically result prepare

title: Compute the Descriptive Statistics for the Parameters — descriptives
text: Dataframe containing parameter bin ("parameter", "bin"), well summary statistics .

what: Estimate a Model from Data — estimate
title: Estimate a Model from Data — estimate
text: Estimation different models particular data set. Uses lm function hood.

title: Estimate a Model from Data — estimate
code: estimate(model, data)  # S4 method for class 'linear' estimate(model, data)  # S4 method for class 'quadratic' estimate(model, data)  # S4 method for class 'cubic' estimate(model, data)  # S4 method for class 'main_effect' estimate(model, data)  # S4 method for class 'interaction' estimate(model, data)  # S4 method for class 'ar1' estimate(model, data)  # S4 method for class 'arx' estimate(model, data)

title: Estimate a Model from Data — estimate
text: model Object representing model used. Note may just class name need particular parameters specified. data Data.frame containing relevant variables, specifically "y", "x", "z", "time". Ideally, variables present data.frame, even applicable particular model.

title: Estimate a Model from Data — estimate
text: List containing result lm "fit" model estimated parameters "model"

title: Estimate a Model from Data — estimate
code: # Example given for the linear model, but also possible for other models x <- rnorm(100) data <- data.frame(   x = x,    y = 3 + 10 * x + rnorm(100) )  estimate(   linear(),   data ) #> $fit #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = y ~ x, data = data) #>  #> Coefficients: #> (Intercept)            x   #>       3.139        9.961   #>  #>  #> $model #> An object of class "linear" #> Slot "parameters": #> [1] 3.138644 9.961004 #>  #> Slot "sd": #> [1] 1.017146 #>  #>

title: Set-up Study — execute_study
text: Given particular simulation model, estimate statistical model compute summary statistics interest. simulation, assume participant set parameters underlie responses throughout full study. study, participant encounters string values independent variable(s) multiple times throughout study, allowing assessment test-retest reliability.

title: Set-up Study — execute_study
code: execute_study(   sim_model,   est_model,   n_participants = 100,   n_outcomes = 20,   n_bins = 5,   parameter_sd = 1,   ICC = 1,   R2 = NA,   save_results = FALSE,   path = file.path("results"),   filename = "results",   statistics = list(descriptives = descriptives, signal = signal, icc = icc, accuracy =     accuracy),   ... )

title: Set-up Study — execute_study
text: sim_model Object model-class containing parameters around participant-specific parameters generated using generate_parameters function. model used simulate data. est_model Object model-class fitted data simulated sim_model n_participants Integer denoting number participants include study n_outcomes Integer denoting number outcomes exists within string. Together n_bins, total number observations per participant becomes N = n_bins * n_outcomes. Defaults 20. n_bins Integer denoting number repeated strings outcomes include study. Together n_outcomes, total number observations per participant becomes N = n_bins * n_outcomes. Defaults 5. parameter_sd (Positive) numeric denoting population standard deviation parameters, therefore indicating many individual differences exist parameter simulating model sim_model. Defaults 1 ICC Numeric 0 1 denoting value ICC want simulate data. specified, change values parameters model across bins, emulating variation across bins therefore consistency can recovered. Defaults 1, meaning parameters change across bins. R2 Numeric 0 1 denoting \(R^2\) model within-person level. specified, compute residual standard deviation allows determinstic part model \(R^2\) specified. Defaults NA, triggering use model-specified residual standard deviation. Passed simulate save_results Logical denoting whether save results. Defaults FALSE path Path folder want save different results. Defaults folder "results" current working directory filename Character denoting delineating name given files contain different results. Defaults "results" statistics Named list containing single-argument functions take estimated generating values parameters perform analyses values. Defaults functions defined _statistics.R_. ... Additional arguments passed simulate_x

title: Set-up Study — execute_study
text: Test-retest reliability results

title: Generate a Random Parameter Set — generate_parameters
text: Numeric matrix size n x k, n number randomly generated parameter sets k number parameters model

what: Compute the \(ICC(A, 1)\) for Participant and Bin. — icc
title: Compute the \(ICC(A, 1)\) for Participant and Bin. — icc
text: study, define \(ICC(, 1)\) : $$ICC(, 1) = \frac{\sigma_\text{participants}}^2$$ \(\sigma^2\) denotes variance. \(ICC\) puts systematic variance – , interindividual differences values parameters – total observed variance parameters, checking whether individual differences can reliably picked .

title: Compute the \(ICC(A, 1)\) for Participant and Bin. — icc
code: icc(data)

title: Compute the \(ICC(A, 1)\) for Participant and Bin. — icc
text: data Named list containing parameter names "parameters", true parameter values "simulated", estimated parameter values "estimated". Typically result prepare

title: Compute the \(ICC(A, 1)\) for Participant and Bin. — icc
text: Dataframe containing parameter ("parameter"), systematic unsystematic variances ("systematic", "unsystematic"), estimated \(ICC(, 1)\) parameter ("icc")

what: Compute the Signal-based Metrics on Standard Errors — signal
title: Compute the Signal-based Metrics on Standard Errors — signal
text: Computes coefficient variation signal--noise ratio. coefficient variation defined : $$CV = \frac{\sigma}{\mu}$$ \(\sigma\) standard deviation \(\mu\) mean estimated parameters. statistic examines relationship observed variation average value parameters. Note coefficient variation interpretable 0 interpretable scale. case models, 0 interpretable ratio scale, coefficient variation interpretable well. However, negative values parameters allowed, something coefficient variation expect, therefore adjust formula : $$CV = \frac{\sigma}{|\mu|}$$ communicating relationship parameter value standard deviations directionless way. random variables, signal noise ratio defined : $$SNR = \frac{E[S^2]}{E[N^2]}$$ \(S\) represents signal \(N\) represents noise.

title: Compute the Signal-based Metrics on Standard Errors — signal
code: signal(data)

text: data Named list containing parameter names "parameters", true parameter values "simulated", estimated parameter values "estimated". Typically result prepare

what: Simulate Data from a Model — simulate
title: Simulate Data from a Model — simulate
text: Method different models allows simulation data models.

title: Simulate Data from a Model — simulate
code: simulate(model, ...)  # S4 method for class 'linear' simulate(model, X = NULL, Xfun = function(x) runif(x, -2, 2), N = 100, R2 = NA)  # S4 method for class 'quadratic' simulate(model, X = NULL, Xfun = function(x) runif(x, -2, 2), N = 100, R2 = NA)  # S4 method for class 'cubic' simulate(model, X = NULL, Xfun = function(x) runif(x, -2, 2), N = 100, R2 = NA)  # S4 method for class 'main_effect' simulate(   model,   X = NULL,   Xfun = list(function(x) runif(x, -2, 2), function(x) runif(x, -2, 2)),   N = 100,   R2 = NA )  # S4 method for class 'interaction' simulate(   model,   X = NULL,   Xfun = list(function(x) runif(x, -2, 2), function(x) runif(x, -2, 2)),   N = 100,   R2 = NA )  # S4 method for class 'ar1' simulate(model, X = NULL, Xfun = function(x) runif(x, -2, 2), N = 100)  # S4 method for class 'arx' simulate(model, X = NULL, Xfun = function(x) runif(x, -2, 2), N = 100)

title: Simulate Data from a Model — simulate
text: model Object one different model classes (e.g., linear, quadratic,...) ... Arguments passed lower functions. Contains arguments explained within function. X Numeric vector matrix containing values independent variables. linear-class, quadratic-class, arx-class, numeric vector suffices, one independent variable required. main_effect-class interaction-class, matrix needed instead, first column taken \(x\) (paired parameter \(b\)) second column taken \(z\) (paired parameter \(c\)). ar1-class, argument ignored. Defaults NULL, forcing user specify value models except ar1-class, alternatively specify function generate values X Xfun argument. Xfun Function simulate values X. take single argument, namely N, specifying many values X simulate. Defaults uniform distribution -2 2. Note output Xfun used alternative X, meaning conform distinction numeric vector numeric matrix specified X argument. N Integer denoting number values simulated. Ignored X defined. Defaults 100. R2 Numeric 0 1 denoting \(R^2\) model. specified, compute residual standard deviation allows determinstic part model \(R^2\) specified. Defaults NA, triggering use model-specified residual standard deviation

title: Simulate Data from a Model — simulate
text: Dataframe containing values variables (\(y\), \(x\), applicable \(z\), named ) time (time)

title: Simulate Data from a Model — simulate
code: # Example given with the linear model, but extends to other models as well. model <- linear(   parameters = c(0, 10),   sd = 1 )  # Simulate for the linear model described above with values for the predictor # drawn from a standard normal distribution simulate(   model,    X = rnorm(10, mean = 0, sd = 1) ) #>    time           y           x z #> 1     1  -3.9920500 -0.27215368 0 #> 2     2 -23.9246587 -2.44668003 0 #> 3     3   0.7299723  0.06548664 0 #> 4     4 -10.4265746 -1.09850890 0 #> 5     5  -5.9163754 -0.63317818 0 #> 6     6 -22.0888443 -2.06365445 0 #> 7     7  27.4305264  2.64893203 0 #> 8     8 -11.8729197 -1.15339839 0 #> 9     9  -3.4819530 -0.34063788 0 #> 10   10   7.9038302  0.78636258 0  # You can also provide your own function to generate the predictor X to the  # function. This is especially useful if this predictor is subject to more  # complicated computations, such as the generation of gambling stimuli simulate(   model,   Xfun = \(x) rnorm(x, mean = 0, sd = 1),   N = 10 ) #>    time           y          x z #> 1     1  -0.3195078  0.1243011 0 #> 2     2  -9.9132721 -0.9984326 0 #> 3     3  11.6943659  1.2333901 0 #> 4     4   2.5590491  0.3404245 0 #> 5     5  -4.0517801 -0.4727025 0 #> 6     6   8.2409064  0.7087531 0 #> 7     7 -16.9760919 -1.5289587 0 #> 8     8   1.4714385  0.2374253 0 #> 9     9 -11.8105088 -1.3128142 0 #> 10   10   8.5704756  0.7470286 0

title: Simulate Values for the Independent Variable for a Model — simulate_x
text: model Object one different model classes (e.g., linear, quadratic,...) ... Arguments passed lower functions. Contains Xfun N generic simulate_x Xfun One functions simulate values independent variable(s). take single argument, namely N, specifying many values X simulate. Defaults uniform distribution bounded -2 2. N Integer denoting number values simulated. Defaults 100.
